title: U.N. warns nearly 5 million people would have officially fled Venezuela since 2015
text:
United Nations and European Union officials expect the mass exodus of Venezuelans to reach 5 million people as calls for neighboring countries to provide refugees with long-term support continues to rise.

At least 4.5 million refugees and migrants have fled the oil-rich nation Venezuela since 2015 over a crippling economy and skyrocketing inflation, according to official figures.

Eduardo Stein, joint special representative of the U.N. refugee and migration agencies, said during Wednesday's meeting in Geneva that there has been a rise in more Venezuelans utilizing illegal crossing points because they lack identity papers.



The crisis has worsened since the United States imposed sanctions, including on the pivotal oil industry, in an effort to oust leftist President Nicolás Maduro in favor of opposition leader Juan Guaidó.

SEE VIDEO BELOW

The United Nations expects 5 million Venezuelans to have fled the oil-rich country since 2015. Pictured above are two children resting near the Venezuela-Colombia border in February 11, 2019

A Venezuelan migrant holds on to a child while they were removed from a makeshift camp in Ecuador on October 1

Venezuelan migrants, pictured above on June 14, 2019, await in line to receive their refugee applications at the Peruvian border

Dozens of nations recognize Guaidó as interim president, saying Maduro rigged a 2018 election.

An average of 5,000 people leave Venezuela daily, although the number fluctuates as more states require visas.

'The experience of other crises in the world shows us that those who would want to go back to Venezuela if the crisis in political terms were to be solved today, it will take a good two years or maybe even more,' Stein told a news conference.

A U.N. regional humanitarian response plan of $739 million for this year is expected to nearly double for 2020, he added.

The initially welcoming attitude to Venezuelans around South America has soured amid accusations they bring crime, crowd the job market, and strain social services.

The United Nations and European Union are hosting a meeting on Oct. 28-29 in Brussels to raise awareness of needs. Donors and officials from the World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank are due to attend, but no Venezuelan representatives.

The United Nations said Wednesday that a humanitarian response plan of $739 million that was set up this year to help out with the Venezuelan crisis is expected to nearly double for 2020. Pictured above are migrants waiting in line and resting in Tumbes, Peru, on June 14, 2019

A photo from June 14, 2019, shows the moment Venezuelan refugees gather at the Peruvian border. Peru has opened its doors to at least 900,000 Venezuelans

'This is the most severe and fastest-growing refugee migrant crisis in Latin American history, at least recent history,' said Walter Stephens, EU ambassador to the U.N. in Geneva.

'There are estimates also that it could further increase if the situation does not change, quickly reaching 5 million.'

Colombia is the top destination for Venezuelan migrants fleeing the long-running crisis, which has caused widespread shortages of food and medicine. Some 1.4 million Venezuelans live in Colombia. Peru has opened its doors to at least 900,000 refugees from the neighboring country.

The flow is overwhelming the financial and administrative capacities of host countries to provide education and health services, Stein said.

'Nine receiving countries have agreed to accept expired (Venezuelan) passports as valid documents. And so with an expired passport you can get a temporary permit sometimes for two years,' he said.

Venezuelan anti-government protesters (pictured on January 23, 2019) hold their national flag as they block traffic during a demonstration in Sao Paulo, Brazil
description: The U.N. said Wednesday that the exodus of Venezuelans could reach 5 million people as they continue to flee the oil-rich country that has crashed due to a crippling economy and high inflation.
